facts.text: On the 21st August, 1940, a preliminary mortgage decree was passed ex parte in a suit instituted by the appellant to enforce a mortgage.

On the 19th September, 1940, the judgment-debtor made an application under Order IX, rule 13, of the Civil Procedure Code for setting aside the ex parte decree, but this application was rejected on the 7th June, 1941.

On the 11th July, 1941, the judgment-debtor filed an application under Section 36 of the Bengal Money Lenders Act, for reopening the preliminary decree, but this application was dismissed for default of appearance on the 20th December, 1941.
Thereafter, a final mortgage decree was passed in favour of the appellant, on the 22nd December, 1941.

The judgment-debtor then made an application under Order IX, rule 9, of the Civil Procedure Code for the restoration of the proceedings under Section 36 of the Money Lenders Act. The application was however dismissed on the 1st June, 1942, both on the ground that no sufficient cause for the non-appearance of the applicant and his failure to take steps in the proceedings was shown and on the ground that no purpose would be served by reopening the preliminary decree after the final decree had been passed.

The judgment-debtor thereafter preferred an appeal to the High Court at Calcutta from the decision dismissing his application under Order IX, rule 9, but the appeal was dismissed for non-prosecution, on the 3rd July, 1944.

On the 9th April, 1945, the appellant filed an application for executing the decree against the original judgment-debtor, though he had died previously, and this application was dismissed for default on the 11th May, 1945.
On the 2nd June, 1945, the present application for execution was filed.
The first court held that the decree was not barred by limitation, but the High Court came to the opposite conclusion.

legal_issues.text: Whether the decree under execution is barred by limitation, specifically whether the execution application filed on 2nd June 1945 is in time, or falls under clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: The case falls under either clause 2 or clause 3 of article 182 of the Indian Limitation Act. Specifically, under clause 3, the application made by the judgment-debtor for reopening the preliminary mortgage decree under Section 36 of the Bengal Money Lenders Act must be regarded as an application for review and time should be held to run from the date of the final order passed in the proceedings connected with that application.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 182 clauses 2 and 3, Indian Limitation Act; Section 36, Bengal Money Lenders Act

court_reasoning.text: It is quite clear that the application for execution having been made more than three years after the date of the final decree, it must be held to be time-barred, unless it falls under clause 2 or 3 of article 182.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The application is more than three years after final decree.

court_reasoning.text: There is no substance in the contention that the application under Section 36 is a review under clause 3 of article 182, as the important words are 'where there has been a review' and 'the decision passed on the review'. The court must have undertaken to review the decree and there must be a decision on the review.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even assuming 'review' in a large sense, the court never undertook or purported to review the decree.

court_reasoning.text: The application under Section 36 for reopening the preliminary decree (not the final decree) was dismissed for default, and the restoration application under Order IX rule 9 was also dismissed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No review of the relevant decree (final decree under execution) was undertaken.

holdings.text: The appellant cannot succeed because the court never undertook or purported to review the decree in question; the execution application is time-barred.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Applications to set aside ex parte decree, restoration of proceedings dismissed for default, certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

statutes_cited.name: Bengal Money Lenders Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Application for reopening preliminary decree, treated as potential review but dismissed for default

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Time for execution application runs from date of final decree or order of appellate court/withdrawal, or decision on review; not applicable here

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by the decree-holder, holding that the execution application filed on 2nd June 1945 is time-barred as it does not fall under clauses 2 or 3 of Article 182 of the Limitation Act, since no review of the decree was undertaken by the court.

key_quotes.text: The only question to be decided in this appeal... is whether the decree under execution is barred by limitation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States the sole issue before the court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, there is no substance in this contention.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects appellant's main argument on limitation

key_quotes.text: These words show that before a case can be brought under article 182, clause 3, it must be shown firstly that the court had undertaken to review the relevant decree or order and secondly, that there has been a decision on the review.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key interpretation of 'review' under Limitation Act
